Description: Limestone statue of Ashamria: a kneeling stelophorous statue of the chief altar attendant of Amun Ashamria, in a long linen skirt and wig and sporting a short beard. The stela consists of one scene at the top and six lines of incised text. Ra-Horakhty is depicted in his barque, Horus at the rudder and Maat at the prow of the boat. A baboon is shown in an attitude of worship above the bark on either side. On the extreme right is a standard, and it and the bark rest on the sky-sign. The text consists of a prayer to Ra-Horakhty on behalf of Ashamria. A column of text is incised down the back-pillar and rear base of the statue containing the usual Hotep-di-nesu formula to Amun-Ra for the deceased. There are traces of blue paint in the hieroglyphs and figures and red paint in the dividing lines between the text.

Exhibition history: Exhibited: 2001-2014, Basel, Switzerland, Antikenmuseum. Long term loan. 2022-2023 7 Oct-26 Feb, Middlesbrough, Dorman Museum, NP Ancient Egyptians
Condition: The statue and stela are fairly well preserved apart from some damage to the edges of the stela and the right arm and base of the statue. The broken base has been restored in modern times, as has the top right corner of the stela where some signs have been lost. These can be restored from early publications when this corner was still intact. The surface of the statue is slightly worn.
